# 🌍 Climate Change {background-color="#1c4982"}

> <span style="color:#b7e4c7; font-style:italic;">*"The evidence for human-caused climate change is overwhelming, and the consequences are real and serious."*</span>  
> <span style="color:#b7e4c7; font-style:italic;">— **Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC, 2021)**</span>



## 🌐 The IPCC: Scientific Foundation

- The **Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)** is the **United Nations body** that provides policymakers with regular scientific assessments on climate change.  
- It **synthesizes** findings from thousands of peer-reviewed studies — it does **not conduct original research**.  
- Its reports provide the **scientific foundation** for international agreements like the **Paris Agreement**.  
- [IPCC AR6 (2021)](https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/) confirms:  

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    “Human influence has unequivocally warmed the atmosphere, ocean, and land.”
    <br><span style="font-size:1.5rem;">— IPCC AR6 (2021)</span>
  </blockquote>
</div>



## 🔮 How the IPCC Projects the Future

- The IPCC combines:
  1. **Climate Models** → simulate how greenhouse gases affect temperature and sea level.  
  2. **Socioeconomic Scenarios** → describe how population, energy, and policy evolve.  



<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    Together, these form the **Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs)** — “what if” futures ranging from rapid decarbonization to continued fossil dependence.
  </blockquote>
</div>
 

## 🌏 Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs)

<div style="display:block; margin:10px;"></div>

<div style="font-size:1.7rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

| **SSP** | **Name / Description** | **Socioeconomic Theme** |
|:--:|:--|:--|
| **SSP1** | *Sustainability* | Green growth, equity, rapid decarbonization |
| **SSP2** | *Middle of the Road* | Continuation of current trends |
| **SSP3** | *Regional Rivalry* | Fragmented world, low cooperation |
| **SSP4** | *Inequality* | Unequal access to technology and adaptation |
| **SSP5** | *Fossil-Fueled Development* | High growth, carbon-intensive economy |

</div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    Each SSP represents a possible pathway for human and economic development.
  </blockquote>
</div>
 
 

 

## ☀️ SSP with Forcing Levels: 1.9, 2.6, 4.5, 7.0, 8.5

A **forcing level** tells us _how much additional heat energy_ the Earth retains due to human activities compared with preindustrial conditions.

<div style="display:block; margin:20px;"></div>

<div style="font-size:1.4rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

| **Scenario** | **Forcing (W/m²)** | **Approx. Warming by 2100** | **Description** |
|:--|:--:|:--:|:--|
| **SSP1-1.9** | 1.9 | ~1.4 °C | Net-zero by 2050; 1.5 °C goal (Paris) |
| **SSP1-2.6** | 2.6 | ~1.8 °C | Strong mitigation |
| **SSP2-4.5** | 4.5 | ~2.7 °C | Intermediate; moderate policy action |
| **SSP3-7.0** | 7.0 | ~3.6 °C | High emissions; limited cooperation |
| **SSP5-8.5** | 8.5 | ~4.4 °C | Fossil-fueled growth; extreme warming |

</div>


<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    Higher numbers = higher greenhouse forcing → greater warming and impacts.
  </blockquote>
</div>

- **Record-breaking heatwaves** across **North America, Europe, and Asia**.  
- **Higher average temperatures** increase **mortality** and reduce **labor productivity**.  

### 💧 **Droughts and Flooding**
- Intensified **hydrological cycle** — some regions get **drier**, others **wetter**.  
- **Greater rainfall variability** increases **agricultural** and **water supply risks**.  

:::

### 🌊 **Sea Level Rise**
- **Melting ice sheets** + **thermal expansion** = **flooding** in **low-lying cities** and **islands**.  
- **Coastal infrastructure** and **ecosystems** are under **growing threat**.  

### 🪸 **Ocean Acidification**
- **Oceans absorb ~25% of emitted CO₂** → **lower pH** → harms **coral reefs** and **shellfish**.

# **The Social Cost of Carbon (SCC)** {background-color="#1c4982"}



## 💰 Unpacking the Social Cost of Carbon

<div align="center">

{{< video https://youtu.be/nDuDUPfJLU0?si=AD0kT4kxeHjpIWCp width="1200" height="600" >}}

</div>


## 🌎 What Is the Social Cost of Carbon?

> **Definition:**  
> The **Social Cost of Carbon (SCC)** is the **monetary estimate** of the economic damages caused by emitting **one additional ton of CO₂** into the atmosphere.

- The "**social cost of carbon**" (SCC) is the present value of future damages from one additional ton of CO2 emissions.
  - Central tool in **Cost-Benefit Analysis** of regulations  
  - Expressed in **\$ per ton of CO₂**
  - Links **climate impacts** to **economic valuation**
  - Used by **governments and firms** to guide **climate-related policy and investment decisions**


## 🧮 How the SCC Is Used in Policy

<div style="text-align: center; width: 77.5%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/scc_explainer.png" alt="Source: Resources for the Future" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-30px;"></div>


::::{.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
#### **If emissions increase...**
→ Multiply extra tons of CO₂ by the SCC  
→ Add to **policy costs**
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
#### **If emissions decrease...**
→ Multiply reduced tons of CO₂ by the SCC  
→ Add to **policy benefits**
:::
::::

:::





<!-- 📘 **Example:**   -->
<!-- Cleaner air regulations → reduced CO₂ emissions → higher net benefits via SCC valuation. -->

 

## ⚙️ How the SCC Is Calculated

<div style="font-size:2rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

<table style="width:100%;">
  <colgroup>
    <col style="width:10%;">
    <col style="width:45%;">
    <col style="width:45%;">
  </colgroup>
  <thead>
    <tr>
      <th>**Step**</th>
      <th>**Process**</th>
      <th>**Purpose**</th>
    </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
    <tr>
      <td><span class="fragment">**1️⃣**</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">Project future **emissions**</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">Based on population, GDP, and energy use</span></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><span class="fragment">**2️⃣**</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">Model **climate response**</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">e.g., temperature increase and sea level rise</span></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><span class="fragment">**3️⃣**</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">Estimate **economic & social impacts**</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">Agriculture, health, energy, and infrastructure</span></td>
    </tr>
    <tr>
      <td><span class="fragment">**4️⃣**</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">**Discount** future damages</span></td>
      <td><span class="fragment">Convert to **present-day values**</span></td>
    </tr>
  </tbody>
</table>

</div>

<!-- - 🧩 SCC = Difference in total damages **with vs. without** an extra ton of CO₂ -->

<div style="display:block; margin:20px;"></div>

- 🧮 Computed through **Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs)** that combine **climate science**, **economics**, and **policy responses** in a single framework.  
  - 💻 Thousands of simulations account for **uncertainty**.



## 🧩 Seven Key Ingredients of the SCC

<div style="text-align: center; width: 100%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/scc.png" style="width: 100%; margin-bottom: -20px;">
  <p style="font-weight: bold;"></p>
</div>


## 🔍 Seven Key Ingredients Explained

<span class="fragment">
1️⃣ **Socioeconomic and Emissions Pathways**  
   Project how the global economy and emissions evolve under different scenarios.    
</span>

<span class="fragment">
2️⃣ **Climate Model**  
   Quantifies how additional CO₂ affects temperature and sea level.    
</span>

<span class="fragment">
3️⃣ **Damage Function**  
   Links physical climate impacts to economic outcomes—agriculture, health, energy, and property losses.    
</span>

<span class="fragment">
4️⃣ **Discounting**  
   Converts future damages into today’s monetary value; the discount rate reflects how we value future generations.    
</span>

## 🔍 Seven Key Ingredients Explained

<span class="fragment">
5️⃣ **Equity**  
   Accounts for how climate damages affect regions and income groups differently.  
</span>  

<span class="fragment">
6️⃣ **Global vs. Domestic Damages**  
   Determines whether to value global harms or focus only on national impacts—an ethical and policy choice.  
</span>

<span class="fragment">
7️⃣ **Uncertainty**  
   Reflects the wide range of possible outcomes from complex climate and economic systems.   
</span> 



## 🔬 Modern IAM Models

- Several major **Integrated Assessment Models (IAMs)** are used to estimate the SCC — including **DICE**, **FUND**, and **PAGE**.  
- A new-generation IAM, the **Greenhouse Gas Impact Value Estimator (GIVE)**, was developed by **Resources for the Future (RFF)** and **UC Berkeley** (Rennert et al., *Nature*, 2022).  
- The GIVE model integrates the latest data on **climate science**, **economic damages**, and **discounting**.  
- Updated estimate:  
<div style="display:block; margin:-30px;"></div>

  $$ \text{SCC} = \$185\ \text{per ton CO₂} $$
- Adopted by the **U.S. EPA (2023)** as the central value → **≈ \$190 per ton**.  
<!-- - This marks a **major increase** from earlier federal estimates (≈ \$50 per ton). -->

- 🔺 [A recent 2025 study](https://sites.google.com/site/adrienbilal) finds SCC values approaching **\$1,500 per ton** (at a 2% discount rate) when accounting for **global temperature shocks**, far significantly higher than previous work.

## 🇺🇸 The U.S. Cost of Climate Inaction

- Climate damages are projected to cost the U.S. economy **~1–4% of GDP annually by 2100** — equivalent to **\$250 billion–\$1 trillion per year (in today’s dollars)**.  
- That’s **comparable to, or larger than, the entire U.S. defense budget**.  
- Even now, **weather and climate disasters already exceed \$100 billion per year** (NOAA).  
- With unchecked warming, these losses will **multiply**, turning today’s “catastrophic” events into the **new normal**.

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    💬 *The extraordinary becomes ordinary — and the cost of inaction is measured in trillions.*
  </blockquote>
</div>

## 🧭 How the Discount Rate Shapes Policy

<!-- Determines how much **future climate damages** are valued in **today’s dollars**. -->

<div style="display:block; margin:15px;"></div>

<div style="font-size:1.75rem; max-width:1000px; margin:0.5rem auto;">

| **SDR (%)** | **SCC (US\$ per Ton CO₂)** |
|:----------------------:|:-------------------------------------------:|
| **1.5%** | \$308 |
| **2.0%** | \$185 |
| **2.5%** | \$118 |
| **3.0%** | \$80 |

<div style="text-align:center; font-size:0.9rem; color:#666;">
SCC estimates are based on the <strong>GIVE model</strong> (RFF & UC Berkeley, 2022)
</div>

| **SDR** | **Interpretation** | **Effect on SCC** |
|:--|:--|:--|
| **High** | Values the future much less than the present | ⬇️ Lower SCC |
| **Low** | Values future generations almost equally | ⬆️ Higher SCC |

</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:15px;"></div>

<div class="fragment" style="font-size:1.75rem; text-align:center; margin-top:1.5rem;">
  <blockquote>
    🧠 The choice of SDR reflects both **empirical evidence** *(expected economic growth, market returns)* and **ethical judgment** *(how much we value future well-being)*.
  </blockquote>
</div>

 

## 🌎 Global vs. Domestic Damages

- **Global SCC:** Reflects worldwide climate impacts  
- **Domestic SCC:** Includes only **U.S. (or national)** damages  
- Because **CO₂ mixes globally**, every ton emitted anywhere affects the whole planet.  
- A **domestic-only** approach captures only **10–20%** of total global damages.  

<span class="fragment">
→ Choice of scope reflects **policy values**:  
Do we count only national welfare, or **shared global responsibility**?
</span>


## ⚖️ Ethical and Policy Implications
<div style="display:block; margin:25px;"></div>

### 🌍 Global Approach
- Recognizes the **shared nature of the atmosphere**  
- Aligns with **international cooperation** (e.g., Paris Agreement)  
- Justifies **stronger domestic action**, since it values global welfare  

<div style="display:block; margin:25px;"></div>

### 🇺🇸 Domestic Approach
- Focuses narrowly on **national self-interest**  
- Yields **lower SCC values** and weaker incentives to cut emissions  
- Often used for **legal or regulatory consistency** in federal rulemaking  


## 🌍 Why a Global Perspective Matters

> “CO₂ knows no borders.  
> A ton emitted in New York warms the planet just as much as one emitted in New Delhi.  
> The true cost of carbon is **global**, even when policies are made domestically.”

- **Global SCC ≈ \$190/ton** (EPA, 2023)  
- **U.S.-only SCC ≈ \$20–\$40/ton** — just a small share of total global harm  
- Because climate impacts are **shared worldwide**, no nation bears the full cost of its own emissions  
<span class="fragment">
→ **Global cooperation is essential** for efficient and fair climate policy
</span>

## ⚠️ Uncertainty


<div style="text-align:center; width: 66.7%; margin: auto;">
  <img src="https://bcdanl.github.io/lec_figs/give-sdr-dist.png" alt="Observed vs reconstructed warming; attribution with human & natural vs natural-only forcing" style="max-width: 1000px; width: 100%;">
</div>

<div style="display:block; margin:-20px;"></div>

Because climate, economic growth, and technology are unpredictable:

- Models simulate **thousands of futures**  
- SCC is best viewed as a **range** rather than a single value  
- Analysts often use a **central case** + “high-impact scenario”



## 🧭 Policy Evolution of the SCC
<div style="display:block; margin:-12.5px;"></div>

- **1981:** Benefit–cost analysis **required for all major federal rules**  
- **2008:** Courts ruled that agencies **must include the SCC** ([*Center for Biological Diversity v. NHTSA*](https://caselaw.findlaw.com/court/us-9th-circuit/1024716.html))  
- **2010–2016:** **Obama administration** established the **Interagency Working Group (IWG)** → developed a **global SCC** (≈ **\$50/ton CO₂**) with SDRs of **2.5%, 3%, and 5%**
- **2017:** **Trump administration** **disbanded the IWG** → adopted **U.S.-only SCC** with **high SDRs (3% & 7%)**, lowering values to **\$1–\$7 per ton**
- **2021:** **Biden administration** **restored the IWG** and reinstated the **interim global SCC = \$51/ton** (2016 value, inflation-adjusted)  
- **2023:** **EPA updated** the estimate to **\$190/ton** using the **GIVE model**  
- **2025:** **Trump administration initiated a major rollback** of SCC methodology under a broader **energy deregulation agenda**
